author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request met all of the guidelines for auto-merging and is scheduled to be merged when the mandatory waiting period (3 days) has elapsed.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have read the package naming guidelines: https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->
don't merge, I still need to change something

I think this got to be a special case...
I just updated my code and rerun the `@JuliaRegistrator register` command but ended here again...

what do I have to do to get this correctly registered with the updated code?

I run `@JuliaRegistrator register` the first time but realised something was broken in my package,
I hence made a comment to this pullrequest to stop the automerge.

Then I run a second `@JuliaRegistrator register` on my new commit, which however, for me surprisingly, didn't open a new pull-request, but adapted this one.

Now I guess, it cannot be automerged, as there many comments.
And more, I am not sure, whether this auto-pullrequest-update-kind-of-thing went well and merging this pullrequest will actually merge the correct new commit.

Maybe it is just a manual merge which I need, don't know.
@schlichtanders  I fail to understand what's the problem

I guess the process of ProxyRegistrator of updating an existing pull-request (which was marked for not-merge) instead of creating a new pullrequest just got me massively confused

I now tried to convert the git-tree-sha1 `d85fef4db37288bd756c71d223e34406055b7414` which is linked in the current state of the pull-request to the actual commit id. That is always super complicated... Today I found this stackoverflow https://stackoverflow.com/questions/48188545/listing-all-commits-given-a-tree-hash-id
which gave me the commitid `ccbd5f24c21354eb92682bd8822791d1df7be521`, which indeed is the up-to-date one.


EDIT: just seeing that you already merged it ~@fredrikekre Hence this only needs to be merged manually~
(and if you have a hint how to get commitid from git-tree-sha1 in an easy and straightforward manner, that would also help alot)

> and if you have a hint how to get commitid from git-tree-sha1 in an easy and straightforward manner, that would also help alot

It is in the first comment of this PR. What do you need it for?

yes, here it is fast, but I wanted to clarify whether the underlying pull request actually also refers to the same git commit (as both the first comment and the underlying pull-request was updated and I was not sure whether the update worked correctly).

Also when working with LocalRegistrator I sometimes face this problem of wanting to know which concrete commit is actually registered... and then I search across the web to find a little snippet, but never found a simple one yet.

body:

title: New package: ProxyInterfaces v1.0.0
